nodes.bodyText: Let's add a line of comment for public method
Added.
For a synchronized method, can we add the callers/threads ?
Added.
Is this comment relevant ?
I can remove it after code review. I thought it will help in making clear how visibility is updated during the review.
can we use perHostOpenDataStreamMap.getOrDefault(remoteHost, new AtomicReference<>(dataStream)).set(dataStream) ?
Fixed.
Should we be more specific and say Network buffers ?

nodes.bodyText: I know we haven't been doing it, but we should add a comment for what the members are used for ?
Done.
If we throw an exception here and don't send the subscription, will we retry later. Can we add a comment to that effect ?
Added the ability to retry subscriptions for all nodes that we don't have a valid subscription state for. Noted it in the javadoc for the method.
Lets add the constant to RcaConsts class
done
It might make sense to increase that timeout ?
Increased to a minute.
Change to log.debug
removed.
Is this really an exception ?
It's more of a metric than an exception, and I changed it to a metric and added  a new exception metric when the scheduler stops due to an exception.
Can we add doc comments for the class ?
Added.
Why do we need 3 threads here?
My bad, I had set it to 3 for testing, changed it to be just 1.
Can you add some documentation or an interface around start and stop functions. What is supposed to happen when these functions are called?
Got rid of the wrappers.
Why 200?
Just carried over the same number that was being used previously. On a 200 node cluster, it can buffer one flow unit from all nodes. I have made it configurable now though.
We can use a long here instead of AtomicLong as that will simplify the code.
Done.
Do you think instead of making it a program constant, we make it part of rca.conf ? So that changing this does not require a code deployment just a PA restart
Made the queue size for the threadpool executor configurable now.
Do we want to remove all the happens-before comments ?
I will get rid of it after the review.
Shouldn't we drain out all the queues, otherwise at restart we will send a bunch of stale messages in the send queue
Done.
doc comment for the class
Added.
For dumpStats, should we also say the amount of payload each queue has ?
Removed dumpstats. Was debug code.
Instead of polling for tasks we should directly post the task into the threadpool using the execute function.
Done.
How did we arrive at this number ? Can we move this to RcaConst class ?

The scheduler's periodicity is 1s, so if we wanted to receive and send in that 1s, setting send and receive periodicity to 250ms will give us two chances(but I guess that explanation doesn't hold water because there is no synchronization across schedulers, now that I think about it), but the higher the frequency, the more chances you get to send/receive - was my thinking. I've changed it from being a poll based model to push based where we queue the message up by calling execute on a threadpoolexecutor as soon as we can so it's not needed anymore.
Probably we should drain all queues ?
Removed file.
change the log message ? kk
Removed file.
same
Removed file.
We dont need to update map on each enqueue. We can use a putifAbsent.
Done.
What change did we make here?
Missed rebase artifact.
How do we handle publish failure?
Publish failures will cause the subscribers to re-send a subscribe if the subscribers don't get flow units from that particular host. This will trigger a re-establishment of the stream.

What happens to stale connections? When do we throw them away? Can we have connection failures where we re-establish a connection?
The case we need to test is -

Node joins cluster.
You are streaming metrics.
Node leaves cluster temporarily and then joins back.
Will we create a new connection and stream data?
We should also track cluster membership changes to add/remove nodes.

Stale connections will result in subscribers resending a single subscribe request and re-establishing the stream.
Added mechanism to check and trigger subscription if the cluster membership reports nodes that the network layer has not seen. And unsubscribe/terminate connection if cluster membership says a node is not part of the cluster.
rca.conf supports comments. We can add a couple of lines where this config is used and what can be the repercussions of setting it too high or too low

nodes.bodyText: Are these lines well formatted ? Maybe this change is not intended  ?

That is how intellij formatted. I think in the previous iteration the '.'s were not aligned, and when it aligns the '.'s one of the lines grows more than 100 character line limit and gets bumped down to the next line.
Looks like when we align the '.'s the line length goes over the limit and it bumps a chunk down to the next line.

I am thinking, if it would be a better idea to buffer this request until we are ready and then heed to it. Given than every node can start and die on their own, we might want to minimize packet transfers if we can. what do you think ? We should definitely add a comment saying that this is safe  and the node that sent it will re-send it again in future and we will act on it then or something along those lines

This will only happen during initial switch on phase of RCA where the framework comes up on master first before being turned on in the data nodes. After that we should not be seeing this. However, I can add buffering as an improvement - will create an issue around it.
cool.
A comment maybe ? :)
Added.

Do we really need this added complexity to set the queue size dynamically ? we can make it require a restart ?
What happens when the old executor was executing and this thread sees a configuration change and tries to update the pool, will we ever be running the same code across two threads ?

It will still need a restart of some sort. The queue length is only read when starting/restarting the controller. Essentially, this lets us change queue size without needing a JAR replacement, just modifying the RCA conf file and restarting should suffice.

What happens when the old executor was executing and this thread sees a configuration change and tries to update the pool, will we ever be running the same code across two threads ?

when we restart, we stop the old threadpool executor. This scenario should not happen.
